text: all these developers you know have this
this window steering element in front of
them uh and often they're using it but
people haven't seen it as a tool for
delivering software uh they see it as a
tool for for building software as to as
kind of an archaic tool
and for for doing things
to create the software but they haven't
seen it as a delivery mechanism for the
software itself
and I think we can do a lot more with it
and I've been experimenting over the
years to see what you can do with a
terminal and if things have moved on
so much
terminals can do 16.7 million colors and
they've got lots of Unicode characters
which you can use to build various kind
of graphics
and and remarkably fast most terminals
will use your your GPU so it can deliver
fast updates at 60 frames a second which
is crazy to me you know it's because uh
you know 20 years ago it was just simple
green text that you typed into and then
you got a few lines of text back
um but now it's using the same
technology as video games
and so we but there's very little code
and projects out there to build
sophisticated applications
um you know curses is the most popular
one it's been around for
for decades but that looks very
rudimentary I mean it's very much rooted
in technology of 20 years ago so I
figured uh what can I do to use all this
power that's available in the terminal
and maybe bring some of the the
improvements which have occurred in the
web world see if I can bring it to
terminal and then build applications
inside the terminal and it turns out
that you can do you can do quite a lot
and what we built is textual which is a
python framework which creates these
applications inside of a terminal and
they look a lot more like web
applications
[Music]
